title: 'Madness': Mining boss issues blistering message after gold mine closure
text:
A﻿ Tasmanian gold mining boss has issued a blistering message to the state government after being ordered to shut down operations over unpaid debts.

Hellyer Gold Mine was issued a cease work notice by the state's Resources Minister Felix Ellis earlier this week with $1 million in royalties still owing to the government.

The mine ﻿– which employs around 70 workers – has been accused of not meeting its financial obligations to the government, suppliers and contractors in the region.

Hellyer Gold Mine CEO Graham Cox pictured with a worker. (Supplied)

However, owners claim its employees have been "unfairly punished".

Chief executive Graham﻿ Cox blasted the decision as "reckless, unncecessary and completely at odds with the state's claims of being open for business".

"This is an act of bureaucratic overreach that puts hardworking Tasmanians out of jobs and jeopardises a world-class, Australian-owned business that has worked hard to meet every obligation placed before it," Cox said.

"We have acted transparently, responsibly and in full cooperation with the Tasmanian government.

"To shut down a compliant, productive and environmentally responsible operation without warning is madness."

Hellyer was reopened on Tasmania's west coast a little over a year ago after being closed for more than a decade.

Cox claims the mining company has been transparent ﻿and has paid back "significant" royalties and taxes owed to the government by former owners, including $8.6 million in Royalties and Environmental Bond.

Hellyer was re-opened inn Tasmania's west coast a little over a year ago. (Supplied)

However, the minister said Hellyer still owes around $1 million.

"When a company extracts and sells a Crown-owned mineral, it must meet its obligations," Ellis said.

"Hellyer has fallen significantly behind in paying their debts due to the crown and other compliance issues have continued to escalate.

"This action is necessary to prevent those matters worsening."

Ellis also alleges there has been a "range" of non-compliance issues at Hellyer, which he said the leadership team have been given a chance to address.

"We've given them multiple opportunities over an extended period of time to rectify these issues," he added.

"Mining operations may only resume once the company has substantively addressed its non-compliances."

Mineral Resources Tasmania (MRT) has confirmed Hellyer's authority to mine under the Mineral Resources Development Act 1995 has been revoked.

Ellis said he has been "deeply disappointed" ﻿with Hellyer's leadership.

"We've been working with them, the ownership and the mine, for more than a year to try and get them back into compliance," he told the ABC.

"They've failed to do so.

"It's important that mining companies are paying their way, [that] they're paying their bills."

Cox, however, remains steadfast that Hellyer has been "blindsided" by the decision.

"Seventy Tasmanians and their families have been blindsided by this decision, people who should be preparing for Christmas are now wondering how they'll afford it," he added.

"We have paid our dues, we have done everything asked of us and yet we've been shut down without warning or reason."

Tasmania's Industry and Resources Minister Felix Ellis. (Facebook)

READ MORE: Storms to hammer Australia from top of NT to bottom of SA ﻿

The mining boss is now calling on Premier Jeremy Rockliff to intervene.﻿

"Tasmania's economy depends on strong industries like mining, agriculture and energy," Cox said.

"If responsible businesses can be treated like this, the entire state's investment reputation is at stake."

Hellyer has been closed during a significant gold price boom in Australia.

﻿The price of gold has recently surged to astronomical highs, reaching $6755 for an ounce last month.

Much of gold's rise has been attributed to its status as a safe-haven asset.

There is a large proportion of goldfields in Tasmania.﻿

Beaconsfield Gold Mine, one of the biggest gold mines in the country, is located in northern Tasmania.

title: Watchdog flags safety concerns for children over pesticide sprayed on berries
text:
Australia's pesticide regulator has flagged fresh health concerns for young children over a chemical sprayed on berries.

With their high nutritional content, raspberries, blueberries and blackberries have become a favourite for families as part of healthier diets.

But the Australian Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority (APVMA) says existing regulations over using dimethoate - an insecticide widely used to stop berries being spoiled by fruit fly - need strengthening to keep people safe.

READ MORE: Storms to hammer Australia from top of NT to bottom of SA

Blueberries have become a regular part of the weekly shopping for many Australians. (Getty)

In a decision announced this week, the national watchdog said children aged between two and six years old who ate berries treated with dimethoate within seven days or less of harvest risked exposure of the chemical beyond safe limits.

The APVMA ruled fruit growers must now wait at least 14 days after applying the pesticide before harvesting to give it more time to degrade.

It said existing label directions needed altering to ensure dimethoate's use on berries did not present "an undue hazard to people".

Until now, growers had to wait one day after spraying blueberries and seven days following the treatment of raspberries and blackberries.﻿

Earlier this year, the APVMA began reviewing potential health hazards from dimethoate amid the growing popularity of berries.

Data from Food Standards Australia and New Zealand showed Australians' consumption of blueberries, blackberries and raspberries has jumped since the last review of the pesticide in 2017.

Health concerns over ﻿dimethoate resulted in European Union countries banning the chemical in 2019.

Industry body Berries Australia told 9news.com.au that figures it collected over the past five years showed ﻿dimethoate usage had fallen.

title: Popular children's product sold nationally recalled due to asbestos fears
text:
A range of brightly coloured children's sand products have been recalled due to asbestos fears.

The recall was issued by the supplier, Educational Colours, for three products which were sold throughout Australia at Officeworks, Educating Kids, Modern Teaching Aids and Zart Art between 2020 and 2025.

The products are labelled as Kadink Sand (1.3kg), Educational Colours - Rainbow Sand (1.3kg), and Creatistics - Coloured Sand (1kg).

A range of brightly coloured children's sand products have been recalled due to asbestos fears. (ACCC)

The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) said the products were recalled because they may contain tremolite asbestos, a naturally occurring asbestos, which was detected in some samples after laboratory testing.

"The ACCC will continue to monitor developments in relation to the products and the recall notice may be updated as new information emerges," the watchdog said in a statement.

Asbestos is a prohibited substance in Australia.

The recall was issued by the supplier Educational Colours. (ACCC)

"We have engaged with Officeworks, who is a major supplier of these products, and they advised that the products have been removed from sale. We expect they will take all the necessary steps to alert their customers," ACCC deputy chair Catriona Lowe said.

"We continue to engage with suppliers and expect all to provide appropriate support to consumers including responding to queries, and providing advice about arranging a refund.

"We urge customers who own any of the products to stop using them immediately and place the sand in a heavy-duty plastic bag and double tape it securely and keep it out of reach of children.

Customers are urged not to dispose of the product in general waste. (ACCC)

"When doing so, in an abundance of caution, customers should take precautions such as a wearing disposable gloves and a mask."

Customers are urged not to dispose of the product in general waste.

Information on the disposal of Asbestos waste, including disposal facilities in your state or territory can be found on The Asbestos and Silica Safety and Eradication Agency website.

Contact recalls@educationalvantage.com on disposal and for seeking a full refund.

A voluntary recall was also issued in New Zealand today for the same products.

title: 'Dangerous' ingredient lurking in food on Aussie supermarket shelves
text:
Researchers are calling for a ban on ﻿"dangerous" ingredient lurking in thousands of food products available at Australian supermarkets.

And consumers have no way of knowing.

New research has revealed ﻿industrial trans fats in food could be putting Australians at increased risk of heart disease.

READ MORE: Money troubles push more and more Aussies into side hustles

A 'dangerous' ingredient is lurking in food on Aussie supermarket shelves, according to research. (Getty)

Industrial trans fats are ﻿created by turning liquid vegetable oils into solid fats.

They're commonly found in ﻿cheap, fried and ultra-processed foods and can significantly raise the risk of heart attack, stroke, and premature death, even in small amounts.

Researchers at The George Institute for Global Health﻿ analysed 28,000 packaged foods and drinks from major supermarket chains including Woolworths, Coles, Aldi, IGA, and Harris Farm.

They found that only four products explicitly listed partially hydrogenated oils, which are the main source of industrial trans fats.

More than 4200 products included ingredients like ﻿vegetable oils without disclosing the inclusion of industrial trans fats.

READ MORE: Russia fights for land back or compo in High Court feud

More than 500 products ﻿potentially contained industrial trans fats and voluntarily reported trans fat content.

But 181 of those ﻿exceeded the World Health Organisation's (WHO) recommended limit of total fat to reduce the risk of heart disease.

More than 30 per cent of the products that only contained potential industrial trans fats also exceeded the limit.

"This study shows that dangerous trans fats are still lurking in our food supply – and consumers have no way of knowing," lead author and Research Fellow at The George Institute Dr Damian Maganja said.

"Australian labelling laws don't require companies to state whether oils are partially hydrogenated or list trans fat content – making it almost impossible to assess how widespread the issue really is."

Cardiovascular disease is already the leading cause of death in Australia and hidden industrial trans fats could be making the issue worse.

READ MORE: UK halts intelligence sharing with US over drug boat attacks

Cardiovascular disease is already the leading cause of death in Australia. (Getty)

Nations around the world have started limiting industrial trans fats in food settings, including Canada, Denmark, France, Germany, Sweden, and the UK.﻿

The EU also introduced a mandatory 2 per cent limit on trans fats in food products.

But Australia doesn't currently ﻿have any mandatory regulation limiting industrial trans fats in food.

Researchers are now calling on federal and state governments to ban industrial trans fats for the good of the nation.﻿

"Without regulation, Australia risks becoming a dumping ground for unhealthy products that increasingly can't be sold elsewhere," said Dr Maganja.

"To truly protect public health, we need mandatory regulation."

title: Top lawyer returns to unfinished business in Wittenoom asbestos saga
text:
Few people have a resume that rivals Melbourne litigator Peter Gordon.

Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander readers are advised this article includes the name and image of an Indigenous person who has died.

One of the country's most prolific lawyers, his firm Gordon Legal has just finalised what could be the biggest class-action settlement in Australian history — the robodebt scandal.

But a case he picked up 40 years ago in the rugged bushland of Western Australia stands out above the rest.

"I look back on this as being a defining moment for occupational health and safety standards in Australia," Mr Gordon said.

"Because it truly was Dickensian in the worst sense of the word."

Peter Gordon has returned to the Wittenoom case, 40 years after he first came to it. (ABC News: Patrick Rocca)

Blue asbestos mined between the late 1930s and mid-1960s in the remote Pilbara town of Wittenoom, 1,400 kilometres north-east of Perth, exposed thousands of people to dangerous asbestos fibres.

Those fibres can cause mesothelioma, a rare but deadly form of cancer affecting the lining of the lungs.

The mine has been linked to more than 2,000 deaths and, given mesothelioma can take decades to develop, that figure will rise.

The making of a young Peter Gordon

In 1987, a 30-year-old Peter was introduced to Wittenoom.

Two years earlier he had won the first mesothelioma negligence case in Australia, drawing the attention of fellow-lawyer John Gordon, who was preparing to represent Wittenoom worker Wally Simpson.

John and Peter Gordon first travelled to Wittenoom in 1987. (ABC News: Patrick Rocca)

The two unrelated Gordons teamed up and flew to Wittenoom to gather evidence for Mr Simpson's case.

A locked gate prevented them from accessing what remained of the closed mine.

"And I thought the only way to solve that problem was to break in," Peter said.

Peter Gordon took this photo of John Gordon in 1987, after they broke into Wittenoom mine site. (Supplied: Peter Gordon)

With no masks or protective equipment, the two lawyers and a professional photographer gathered what would later become crucial evidence of the mine's working conditions and dangerous levels of asbestos dust.

"It was a really dangerous thing to do," Peter said.

"Forty years later, I haven't got mesothelioma, but people have got it for much less exposure than that."

The trespass began what Peter describes as a years-long "war" with the Colonial Sugar Refining (CSR) company, which owned Wittenoom's mining operations from the early 1940s.

Peter Gordon (second from right) was 30 years old when he first came to Wittenoom. (Supplied: Peter Gordon)

It is a war he thought ended in 1988, when CSR lost a major compensation case brought by German-born Wittenoom worker and mesothelioma victim Klaus Rabenalt.

For the first time in an Australian industrial negligence case, a company was forced not only to compensate a worker, but to pay extra damages as punishment for its behaviour.

"It was one of those sort of movie moments … there was pandemonium in the courtroom," Peter said.

But the story was far from over.

Unfinished business

The impact of the Wittenoom disaster on the area's traditional owners has, until recent years, flown under the radar.

But the Banjima people continue to suffer almost 60 years after the mine's closure.

More than 3 million tonnes of deadly mining waste remain nestled in the gorges surrounding Wittenoom. (Supplied: Dale Hawkins)

More than 3 million tonnes of mining waste laced with blue asbestos fibres is yet to be cleaned up.

Wittenoom now sits within a 46,000-hectare exclusion zone, preventing the Banjima people from accessing part of their traditional land.

Despite years of lobbying from the Banjima Native Title Aboriginal Corporation (BNTAC), the WA government is yet to commit to a full remediation of the site.

In 2023, Banjima elders gave the BNTAC board permission to prepare for litigation to force the government to act.

Peter soon got a call from BNTAC chief executive Ed Armstrong.

"I was of course delighted to help and felt an obligation to help," he said.

" The Banjima people have the highest per capita incidence of mesothelioma in the world. "

Legal fight moving closer

In September, Peter and Banjima representatives sat face-to-face with West Australian Premier Roger Cook.

They laid out a detailed proposal, informed by expert analysis, for the remediation of the contaminated zone.

They also came with a warning — if the government did not agree to take substantive action before the end of the year, they would take the matter to court.

The campaign to clean up Wittenoom is the subject of a new documentary, Yurlu Country, featuring the late Banjima elder Maitland Parker (pictured). (Supplied: Illuminate Films)

"We can't wait forever," Peter said.

"The Banjima people are entitled not to have a cheap and nasty solution to this.

"If it costs billions of dollars to do, then so be it.

"That's the [government's] obligation."

Peter said he believed the premier wanted to do the right thing by the Banjima people.

"Sometimes you can look into the eyes of someone and believe they've got goodness in their heart," he said.

"And that's the impression I formed of him."

WA Premier Roger Cook has called Wittenoom a "tragedy on a massive scale". (ABC News: Courtney Withers)

In public statements since the Banjima meeting, the premier has acknowledged the situation.

"Wittenoom is a tragedy on a massive scale," he told reporters earlier this month.

"[Banjima] put to us a rather ambitious proposal — we've asked our teams to look at that and see how we might help out."

To right a wrong

Peter said he hoped the premier would recognise that Wittenoom did not have to be a burden for his government.

"This is a responsibility but it's also a privilege; it's a privilege to have the opportunity to right a wrong," he said.

"I've had the privilege of acting in a large number of very big and important cases … but I don't think there's been a more important one than this.

title: McLaren orders part of 'perfect storm' that began Piastri's F1 form slump
text:
Oscar Piastri has described his Azerbaijan Grand Prix weekend, where he committed a false start and crashed on the first lap, as "the worst weekend I've ever had in racing".

Speaking on F1's Beyond The Grid Podcast released Thursday morning (AEDT) after being recorded before last weekend's São Paulo Grand Prix, Piastri also suggested several factors, including McLaren's team orders from the previous race, may have contributed to it.

In a wide-ranging interview he spoke about his battle for the drivers' championship, advice he received from manager Mark Webber, and his thoughts on the upcoming Ashes series which begins in Perth next week.

But one of the more intriguing moments of the hour-long podcast was Piastri discussing his disastrous Azerbaijan Grand Prix and how the lingering effects of the previous weekend were still on his mind.

In Azerbaijan, Piastri crashed in qualifying, committed a false start in the race, then crashed on the first lap.

All this happened while the Australian held a 31-point lead in the drivers' championship over Lando Norris.

Piastri hinted that the controversy of the previous round may have played a role in the poor weekend in Baku.

At Monza, Max Verstappen was a runaway leader while Norris was comfortably second and Piastri a few seconds behind in third.

Late in the race and needing to make a pit stop for both drivers, McLaren made the decision to pit Piastri first and then Norris after.

Piastri's stop was perfect, but an agonisingly slow stop for Norris meant the Australian was able to overtake him with less than 10 laps remaining in the grand prix.

Piastri, who held a season-high 34-point lead in the championship, was ordered by McLaren to hand the position back to Norris.

"So I don't really get what's changed here, but if you really want me to do it then I'll do it," Piastri protested during in the race, before ceding the position.

That moment trimmed Piastri's lead down to 31 points and became one of the season's most talked-about moments.

In the aftermath, Piastri said McLaren's decision was fair, but on the Beyond The Grid Podcast the Australian said it was one of many things that he believes contributed to his horror weekend in Baku a fortnight later.

Piastri set for test of 'character' Oscar Piastri will have to show "character" after his recent F1 disappointments says his manager, former Australian ace Mark Webber.

"Ultimately [it's] a combination of quite a few things," Piastri said.

"Obviously the race before that was Monza, which I didn't feel was a particularly great weekend from my own performance, and there was obviously what happened with the pit stops.

"But then also in Baku itself, Friday was tough, things weren't working. I was overdriving, I wasn't very happy with how I was driving and ultimately probably trying to make up for that a little bit on Saturday.

"I think there was kind of some things in the lead-up, let's say, that were maybe not the most helpful and then things that happened on the weekend.

"We had an engine problem in FP1 that kind of unsettled things a bit, and then I was driving not that well. We were on C6 tyres [Pirelli's softest compound] that weekend, which are notoriously tricky to handle. There were just a lot of little things that eventually kind of added up.

"Baku was the perfect storm of quite a few things which obviously was a pretty terrible weekend.

"There's no beating around the bush. That's the worst weekend I've had in racing."

The Australian added that his weekend in Baku was also "useful", stating that he was able to learn a lot from his experience.

Stream End Game with Tony Armstrong on ABC iview Tony Armstrong tackles Australia's overdue reckoning with racism in sport with the help of some of its biggest sports stars.

Piastri has not stood on the podium since that day in Monza, after finishing in the top three 14 times in the 16 grands prix to that point.

He is also yet to finish ahead of Norris or Verstappen in a grand prix since then.

Piastri was denied the chance to finish on the podium in Brazil after being handed a controversial 10-second penalty for a collision with Mercedes driver Kimi Antonelli, despite several in the paddock believing the Australian was not wholly responsible for the crash.

Piastri is now 24 points behind Norris with three rounds — or three grands prix, one sprint — remaining in the season.

The margin is Norris's largest lead in the drivers' championship this season.

He could finish second in all remaining races and win the drivers' championship.

F1 returns to the United States on November 20-22 for the third-last round of the championship.

The Las Vegas Grand Prix will begin at 3pm AEDT on Sunday, November 22.

title: Australia's unemployment rate slips to 4.3 per cent
text:
Australia's unemployment rate declined to 4.3 per cent in October, down from 4.5 per cent in September, in seasonally adjusted terms.

Economists say it has dashed the chances of any near-term interest rate cut.

"If there was ever the slightest chance the RBA could have played Santa and delivered a surprise rate cut at its final meeting of the year next month, it was effectively wiped out following today's firm labour market report," said BetaShares chief economist David Bassanese.

RBA warns economy in danger of being 'boxed in' to slow growth The central bank's deputy governor says it's "more plausible" to wonder whether rates can go much further than to forecast further cuts.

Bureau of Statistics data show the number of employed people increased by 42,200 last month, and the number of unemployed fell by 17,000.

By dropping back to 4.3 per cent, the unemployment rate has returned to the level it was sitting at in June, July, and August, before it popped higher in September.

"This supports the view that last month's increase was more likely a statistical variation than the start of a labour market downturn," BDO chief economist Anders Magnusson said.

"The October result reflects strong job creation and reducing unemployment in a healthy labour market."

The participation rate remained steady at 67 per cent in October, and the employment-to-population ratio remained at 64 per cent, in seasonally adjusted terms.

The underemployment rate fell by 0.2 percentage points to 5.7 per cent.

What does it mean for interest rates?

Federal Treasurer Jim Chalmers said the decline in the unemployment rate in October was a "very positive result".

"Unemployment is down again, 1.2 million jobs have now been created on our watch, and in the past month alone we saw 55,000 new full time jobs," he said.

"This is a very positive result that shows the progress we've made together on the economy despite difficult global circumstances."

RBA holds interest rates in November The Reserve Bank has kept interest rates on hold at 3.6pc after hotter-than-expected inflation in the September quarter squashed hopes of a rate cut.

But economists say it's clear that there won't be any rate cuts on the RBA's near-term agenda.

"Today's report will affirm the RBA's view that the labour market and the economy more generally remain relatively "tight", limiting its ability to support stronger economic growth though lower interest rates anytime soon," Mr Bassanese said.

"Rates can be cut next year, though it will require strong evidence of an easing in inflationary pressures despite the tight economy, or a greater weakening in the economy than seen to date."

Last week, the Reserve Bank released official forecasts projecting that the unemployment rate would stabilise around 4.4 per cent through to the end of next year, which was a slight upward revision from its previous forecast of 4.3 per cent.

"That view appears broadly consistent with today's figures," Mr Magnusson said.

Employment growth still gradually slowing down

EY chief economist Cherelle Murphy said the RBA had already highlighted that the economy may be close to its supply capacity, which means it could not cut the cash rate much further, if at all, without generating inflation.

"Recent data showing a surprise uptick in underlying inflation and a continuation of the tight jobs market means there may be no more interest rate cuts in the foreseeable future," she said.

However, she said it was also clear that the rate of growth in employment had been slowing down over the last two years.

National property prices rise Australia's property market is seeing rising demand, with a rise in both first home buyers and investors pushing up house prices.

"Employment growth has slowed to 1.6 per cent in annual terms, likely reflecting an easing in demand for labour in the non-market sector, such as health, education, and general government services from elevated levels," she said.

Callam Pickering, Asia Pacific economist at global job site indeed, agreed with that assessment.

"Australian employment growth has been sluggish this year," he said.

"Even after adding another 42,000 people in October, employment has increased by just 160,000 people over the first 10 months of the year. That compares to a gain of 325,000 people over the same period last year.

"The main reason for this slowdown has been reduced hiring in health care and social assistance — the industry that drove so much of Australia's post-pandemic job boom.

"Thus far the private sector, which has been heavily impacted by a challenging economic environment, hasn't been able to fill the gap created by reduced hiring elsewhere," he said.

title: Fossil fuel emissions still rising despite renewable energy growth: report
text:
Global fossil fuel emissions are projected to hit another record high in 2025, according to an annual stocktake of carbon dioxide (CO2) levels.

That is despite an anticipated drop in overall human-caused emissions thanks to a reduction in practices like deforestation.

The latest CO2 budget from the Global Carbon Project expects a 1.1 per cent increase in fossil fuel emissions, compared to 2024, driven by continued growth in the use of coal, oil and gas.

The budget has been released as nations gather in Brazil for the COP30 meeting to discuss ways of reducing emissions.

If emissions stay on this trend, it could mean the world locks in an average temperature rise greater than 1.5 degrees Celsius compared to pre-industrial levels within four years.

A global target of keeping warming to a 1.5C long-term average would limit the severity of the extreme weather changes that come with every extra 0.1 degrees of heat.

Australian climate scientist Pep Canadell, who is the executive director of the project and also works at the CSIRO, said year-to-year growth of fossil fuel emissions was a concerning trend.

"There's now a very urgent requirement of a peak and decline [in CO2 emissions] to really start the climate stabilisation path," he said.

Pep Canadell is the executive director of the Global Carbon Project and a chief research scientist in CSIRO's environment team. (Supplied: CSIRO)

But while Dr Canadell said there might be "doom and gloom" in the latest figures, there was some good news.

Australia was recognised in the carbon budget for the first time as one of 35 countries significantly decarbonising, while lifting its economy, and some of the world's biggest CO2 emitters have been hitting major green energy milestones.

"China might be peaking [its CO2 emissions], this is not a small thing, this is a humungous thing," Dr Canadell said.

"India is participating in the revolution of green energy.

"We're certainly building towards that infrastructure revolution of low- and no-carbon energy systems."

It's an "infrastructure revolution" that Australia is being encouraged to take advantage of to meet growing electricity demand, as some of its politicians argue over the merits of "net zero" emissions.

What is the Global Carbon Project?

The Global Carbon Project is an international science effort to understand Earth's carbon cycle.

"Budgets" for the three main greenhouse gases — CO2, methane and nitrous oxide — are created by the group to help inform global emissions reduction policies.

The carbon budget counts up human-produced emissions — such as fossil fuel combustion and deforestation — and then subtracts the amount of CO2 stored in carbon sinks like oceans and forests.

What remains from this equation is the CO2 that goes into the atmosphere and contributes to the greenhouse gas effect.

One of the big takeaways from the 2025 budget is that while fossil fuel emissions are projected to increase, total human-caused CO2 emissions are expected to dip slightly by the end of the year.

That is because there has been a decline in changes to land use like deforestation, which removes CO2-storing vegetation from a landscape.

But, despite this decline, the CO2 budget stated the combined effects of a warming climate and deforestation had still turned tropical forests in South-East Asia and parts of South America from sinks of CO2 to sources.

The finding reinforced the need, according to the budget authors, to halt deforestation to prevent further sink-to-source transitions.

Stopping these sorts of transitions can help prevent emissions caused by a "climate feedback" — a phenomenon where direct human-caused CO2 emissions change the natural environment to the extent extra emissions are created.

About 8 per cent of CO2 emissions to make it into the atmosphere since 1960 have been due to climate feedback, the latest CO2 budget found.

Green shoots in China and India

While fossil fuel emissions are increasing globally, there are positive signs from major emitters like China and India.

Dr Canadell said India was bypassing fossil fuels like gas in adopting more renewable energy.

Meanwhile, China's total CO2 emissions appear to have plateaued over the past three years.

Frank Jotzo, a professor of environmental and climate change economics at the Australian National University, said China was pushing the world towards more clean energy.

"The amount of wind turbine and solar transmission investment in China is staggering … it's well over half of global investment," he said.

Professor Jotzo said countries like Australia should take advantage of the low cost of clean energy equipment.

"What can we learn from it? Well, deploy, deploy, deploy," he said.

" Solar panels are now so cheap, you might as well use it as a fencing. "

What does net zero mean? The Coalition is debating whether to dump its commitment to the net zero climate target. Here's what that term actually means.

However, the United States appears on track to experience a 1.9 per cent increase in emissions compared to 2024.

That has been attributed to a cold start to the year lifting the demand for heating, which was filled by coal because of high gas prices.

Dr Canadell said the emissions story in the US was complex.

"The current administration has changed some of the legislation that was put in place by the previous one and it will have an effect," he said.

"[But] I don't think that's going to reverse the decarbonisation path that the US has already engaged heavily in the past 15 years."

Thirty-five countries decreasing emissions and boosting economies

Another positive out of the CO2 budget is the increase in countries that are considered to be achieving significant decreases in emissions while seeing a lift in their economy over a 10-year period.

Australia joined what became a list of 35 countries for the first time this CO2 budget, compared to 18 countries in the previous 10-year period (2005‒2014).

Professor Jotzo said Australia still needed more rapid progress if it was to meet its national emissions reduction targets.

Meanwhile, an analysis by the international energy think tank Ember, also released today, forecasts that 2025 will be the first year without growth for fossil fuel-derived electricity globally.

Report author Nicolas Fulghum, a senior data analyst for Ember, said extraordinary growth in solar generation had enabled clean power sources to increase fast enough to cover all new electricity demand.

"This resulted in the expected stagnation in fossil generation in 2025," he said.

"Whether fossil generation will fall, or show a minor rise again next year, depends on the speed of demand growth and conditions in 2026 and beyond.

"Structurally, we are now at the point where clean power is growing fast enough to keep fossil fuels from rising further."

But as global electricity demand rises, thanks to factors like electric vehicle uptake and a need for more data centres, Mr Fulghum said there would need to be a faster build-out of solar and wind power to meet more ambitious climate targets.

"[This needs to happen] to not only meet, but exceed demand growth consistently and displace existing fossil fuel generation," he said.

title: Heavy metal band embarks on 16-hour round trip for 40-minute gig
text:
In the quiet town of Ceduna on the far west coast of the Eyre Peninsula, the beating of drums and scream of guitars echoes throughout the old Scout and Guide Hall.

Sitting across the road from a cemetery, the hall serves as a rehearsal space for the town's only heavy metal band, KNAW.

The band is gearing up for its first capital city show in Adelaide, which will involve a 16-hour round trip for the chance to play a 40-minute set.

Robert Pav belts out a scream. (ABC Eyre Peninsula: Emma Pedler)

Lead guitarist Callan Slattery, 20, said it might seem "a little extreme".

"But for us, it's a thing we've got to do," he said.

"Bands from cities won't come out to regional areas like this often."

The band has big dreams of playing on a festival stage one day.

But being so isolated from the heavy metal community creates unique roadblocks.

KNAW rehearse in the town's old Scouts hall. (ABC Eyre Peninsula: Emma Pedler)

"We've talked to a few festivals and put our names out there," Slattery said.

"I think because they see we're from the middle of nowhere … I don't think it excites them for whatever reason, it seems to be a bit of a thing with small bands, especially from rural areas like this."

With limited venues to play at in Ceduna, the band will play anywhere that lets them — often for free.

"You might get a tab on the bar, but we get up there and make our noise," Slattery said.

Makenzi Harrison plays some heavy riffs during a rehearsal session. (ABC Eyre Peninsula: Emma Pedler)

"That's the hardest thing; finding places that are happy to have such extreme music and such energetic and loud shows.

"There is a fair bit of music [in Ceduna] but it's more so around the poppy, country stuff.

"It's hard to end up on the same bill as that sort of thing."

Breaking through

In the Melbourne triple j studio, Jack Bergin pores over the latest alternative music coming in from across the country.

After more than a decade touring as the vocalist for hardcore outfit Void of Vision, Bergin is the host of the station's flagship heavy music program, CORE.

Jack Bergin says he has seen a shift in heavy bands playing more in the regions. (ABC News: Billy Draper)

He said it could be hard for regional bands to find their audience.

"It's very limited to what you can do in a regional town; I dare say it's quite a niche genre, especially in heavy music where you can only meet a handful of people," he said.

"And you've reached your ceiling quite early on in terms of that."

While many bands from regional towns hope to move to a major city to record and play bigger capacity venues, Bergin said cost-of-living pressures often made that unrealistic.

"It's a very tricky situation for a lot of regional acts that they find themselves in at the moment," he said.

While capital city shows were needed for exposure, Bergin said he had seen renewed interest in regional touring from heavier bands.

"I think we're starting to see a bit of a change, I know regional touring in a larger aspect for some of our more household names is coming back big," Bergin said.

KNAW members meet to rehearse at the former Guides and Scouts hall in Ceduna. (ABC Eyre Peninsula: Emma Pedler)

"If we can keep continuing to reintroduce these smaller towns and have more of these flagship acts come through, a lot of the locals will see that and they will respond to that."

A nursery for the music industry

Four hundred kilometres south of Ceduna in Port Lincoln, Sound City owner Mike Pearson has been gearing up for a busy summer of hosting shows.

Mike Pearson says local venues across Australia are struggling with rising insurance costs. (ABC Eyre Peninsula: Duncan Bailey)

He said alternative music venues were needed to showcase different genres.

"It's the nursery for the whole music industry … reducing the number of venues that alternative bands can play in, they've got nowhere to play and have to invent their own gigs," Pearson said.

"The flow-on effect is to the wider music industry.

" Without alternative music venues and places for artists to express different types of music, it threatens the whole industry. "

Pearson said the challenges faced by live music venues were not exclusive to the regions.

Juran Miller, Robert Pav and Callan Slattery hang out in their Ceduna rehearsal space. (ABC Eyre Peninsula: Emma Pedler)

"Live music venues are struggling everywhere; there's a multitude of reasons for that," he said.

He said costs such as insurance had become out of reach for a lot of venues.

"But with a struggle comes an opportunity that forces venues to be a point of difference and offer things that people want to see and hear and do," he said.

Slattery said KNAW had no plans of giving up anytime soon.

Callan Slattery says the band will not throw in the towel just because of the long distances. (ABC Eyre Peninsula: Emma Pedler)

"I don't think there is really much that would stop us," he said.

"We all really want to do it and will jump at any chance we get to do something like this.

"We would really love to have more heavy music festivals close to home … that's the hardest thing, finding the places that will want to have you there."

title: Queensland town fights to keep beloved caravan park
text:
Standing next her humble caravan with an unobstructed view of the glassy waters of Hervey Bay, retiree Pamela Dibbon reflects on some of her fondest memories of the town.

"It's a lovely place — it's the best beach along here," she says.

Every summer for the past eight years, Ms Dibbon and her husband have travelled from Victoria to Hervey Bay, a three-hour drive north of Brisbane, to stay at Torquay Caravan Park.

Pamela Dibbon says she will reconsider coming back to Hervey Bay if the caravan park shuts. (ABC Wide Bay: James Taylor)

But now the council is considering whether to close the park, one of four it runs in the town.

"I'm just so used to this park and we just sort of feel like it's the only place we'd go," Ms Dibbon says.

Experts say her dilemma is experienced by many travellers as more councils look to walk away from caravan parks, despite growing demand.

Green space or caravan parks?

Last year, Fraser Coast Regional Council unanimously passed a motion to suspend a planned $8 million upgrade of the caravan park.

Councillor Zane O'Keefe said the park was taking up valuable space on Hervey Bay's seaside esplanade, which should be accessible to the public.

But ex-councillor Sue Brooks said residents had not complained about feeling crowded.

"The only time you can't access the barbecue is if someone's having a wedding or a celebration and there's other ones close by that people can access," she said.

The Torquay Caravan Park has been a popular spot for many years. (Supplied: Hervey Bay Historical Village & Museum)

The council proposed alternative uses for the site, including an open green space or a playground.

But these proposals led to a public outcry and community group Save the Torquay Caravan Park launched a petition and held protests calling for the council to reconsider its decision.

The petition has about 12,000 signatures.

Sue Brooks says the caravan park issue has "united" the people of Hervey Bay. (ABC Wide Bay: James Taylor)

Ms Brooks said she was surprised by the strength of the public's support.

"The issue has united our community like none other," she said.

A council survey attracted 4,385 responses, the most for any community engagement process, with 76 per cent of respondents preferring to retain the caravan park.

Council will consider the survey results at a meeting next month.

Closure concerns

Business owners operating near the park said they could be forced to close if the caravan park was turned into public parkland.

A Caravan Parks Association of Queensland report estimated the site supported about 45 jobs and could contribute $5.56 million to the local economy.

Aimee Chapman says the closure of the caravan park could have detrimental impacts on her pharmacy. (ABC Wide Bay: James Taylor)

Pharmacy manager Aimee Chapman said she provided medication to grey nomads visiting from the southern states in summer and was worried about the "detrimental" impact its closure could have on her business.

She worries about the potential "let go of staff because we wouldn't be able to stay afloat without the influx of people coming through".

Saving ratepayers

In September, the North Burnett Regional Council said it would relinquish ownership of four caravan parks.

A spokesperson said operating caravan parks was outside the scope of local government and that the council would seek to transfer the ownership and management of the parks to private operators.

The decision was made to "improve council's financial sustainability in the long-term", the spokesperson said.

In July, North Burnett Regional Council handed down a 25 per cent rate increase to cover increasing costs of utilities and services.

Experts say rising rates to fund the caravan parks could cause friction with local residents. (ABC Wide Bay: James Taylor)

Southern Cross University tourism researcher Rodney Caldicott said many councils were looking to offload caravan parks for that reason.

He said councils passing on rising maintenance costs for caravan parks to ratepayers could drive resentment in the community, although that did not appear to be the case in Hervey Bay.

"So the local ratepayers say, 'We just got a rate rise so that we can look after these Victorians to come up here and have a great time in the prime location and I can't afford to live beside the coast,'" Mr Caldicott said.

"So you get all that community feeling."

He said councils had to choose between revenue and residents.

"They've got to think, if they've not got the revenue from the caravan park to help support or even subsidise the maintenance of their parkland, it's got to come from the ratepayers somewhere, somehow," Mr Caldicott said.

Michelle Weston says closing down caravan parks could deter visitors from staying in regional areas. (Supplied: Michelle Weston)

Caravan Parks Association of Queensland chief executive Michelle Weston said more councils were looking at alternative management options for caravan parks rather than closing them altogether.

"It's not unusual for councils to switch between leasing their caravan parks out and having a management contract in place," she said.

But she said the closures of caravan parks could affect tourist numbers in regional areas.

"There just wouldn't be the capacity for them to stay in the commercial caravan parks in the region, particularly during the peak periods," Ms Weston said.

title: Players in First Guardian, Shield sued after Australians lose more than $1b
text:
Australia's corporate watchdog is suing Interprac — the licensee that oversaw financial planners — over alleged failures that led to the collapses of the Shield and First Guardian schemes.

The Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) is also suing ratings agency SQM Research, saying its "processes fell short of expected standards when it published 'favourable' ratings for the Shield Master Fund".

ASIC is also taking action against MWL Financial Services, former director Nicholas Maikousis, and lead generator Imperial Capital Group Australia over alleged Shield advice failures.

On the day ASIC unveiled its hit list for the year ahead, it said a key focus was prosecuting people involved in the collapses of the First Guardian and Shield schemes, which led to people losing over $1 billion of their retirement savings.

ASIC alleges thousands of Australians were exposed to poor financial advice and significant risks from the Shield and First Guardian schemes through critical oversight and compliance failures by Interprac.

Loading...

ASIC alleges Interprac representatives gave 'poor advice'

ASIC has commenced civil penalty proceedings in the Federal Court against Interprac, saying that the licensee failed to ensure its former authorised representatives — Ferras Merhi's Venture Egg and former financial adviser Rhys Reilly — who gave thousands of people financial advice, complied with the best interests obligations and had adequate risk management systems.

ASIC said together, the Interprac representatives advised about 6,843 clients to invest about $677 million of their superannuation into Shield and First Guardian.

Interprac sits under ASX-listed Sequoia, which on Thursday entered a trading halt after the ASIC announcement.

ASIC has commenced separate proceedings against Mr Merhi over Shield and First Guardian, recently securing Federal Court interim orders restraining Mr Merhi from operating within the financial services industry.

Mr Merhi has previously told ABC News: "Every allegation of unlawful conduct that ASIC has made, and any allegation it might yet make, will be strenuously defended in the court proceedings".

Ferras Merhi is himself under ASIC investigation for placing thousands of people into the First Guardian and Shield products, and says allegations "will be strenuously defended". (Supplied.)

Mr Reilly has previously denied preparing, providing, or presenting the Statement of Advice that led to some individuals investing in First Guardian. He has been contacted for comment on ASIC's latest action against Interprac.

ASIC deputy chair Sarah Court said Interprac's alleged oversight and compliance failures "exposed thousands of Australians to poor advice and significant financial risk".

"We allege Interprac failed to ensure certain authorised representatives acted in their clients' best interests, contributing to hundreds of millions of dollars of superannuation being invested in products that were unsuitable, high risk and costly," Ms Court said.

"We allege that no competent financial adviser could have recommended Australians invest large amounts of their superannuation in these funds, and that Interprac — as licensee — should have been alert and responsive to the significant risk this conduct posed to clients, but it failed on many levels."

Sarah Court says ASIC alleges no competent financial adviser could have recommended Australians invest large amounts of their superannuation in Shield and First Guardian.

ASIC alleges Interprac failed to have in place an adequate process for approving financial products it allowed onto its approved product list, including Shield and First Guardian, and relied entirely on external research to add those funds to its approved investments list for advisers.

It also alleges the license failed to respond appropriately to the use of lead generators Imperial Capital Group Australia and AGAT Business, and alleges it failed to respond adequately to news that payments had been made to Mr Merhi's companies by entities associated with First Guardian and Shield.

It also alleges Interprac failed to enforce or maintain a hold on new investments into Shield and First Guardian after Interprac's managing director and responsible manager, Garry Crole, acknowledged serious issues with both funds.

In a recent exclusive interview with ABC News, Mr Crole admitted that "maybe we could have done more" to prevent First Guardian and Shield losses.

Loading...

ASIC also alleges Interprac failed to prevent the use of a "negative consent" practice, which led to some clients' superannuation being invested in Shield and/or First Guardian without express consent from those clients.

It alleges the licensee failed to respond adequately to significant inflows of investment into Shield and First Guardian.

The corporate cop also alleges it failed to provide adequate responses to client complaints about advice from its representatives to invest in Shield or First Guardian and instead relied on a "template" response which often failed to consider the appropriateness of the advice.

It alleges that Interpac failed to respond adequately or impose meaningful consequences in response to serious compliance issues, including failings repeatedly identified in audits.

ASIC is seeking declarations, civil penalties, and orders to restrain Interprac from carrying on a financial services business.

InterPrac said it had received notification from ASIC.

"InterPrac is unable to provide further information at this time and will defend its position on such allegations vigorously," a spokesman said.

ASIC sues SQM Research, alleging misleading reports related to Shield

ASIC is also taking action against ratings agency SQM Research, alleging it prepared reports containing misleading representations and its processes fell short of expected standards when it published "favourable" ratings for the Shield Master Fund.

Deep flaws in Australia's $4.3 trillion system exposed The collapses of the First Guardian and Shield schemes have exposed deep flaws in the regulation of Australia's $4.3 trillion superannuation sector.

SQM Research published reports in October 2021, March 2022 and October 2022, that rated the different classes of Shield as "3¾ stars, Favourable".

The SQM Research reports were provided to financial advisers and superannuation trustees who recommended or on-boarded Shield onto Australians.

About 5,800 people invested their superannuation savings into Shield, in many cases, after receiving advice from financial advisers.

SQM Research's owner and managing director, Louis Christopher, told ABC News: "We are assessing the claim and will let our position [be] known in due course".

Louis Christopher says SQM is assessing ASIC's claim. (ABC News: John Gunn)

The advisers often told investors to roll over their existing superannuation balances into a choice superannuation fund available on a platform which had on-boarded Shield.

ASIC alleges that SQM Research failed to obtain the information it needed to properly assess Shield and alleges it failed to properly consider inconsistencies in information it received when preparing its reports about Shield.

The corporate watchdog also alleges that SQM "misrepresented" that it had a reasonable basis for giving Shield a "favourable" rating and had exercised reasonable care and skill in doing so.

It alleges SQM made misrepresentations that understated the percentage of funds managed by parties related to Shield and the asset allocation of Shield.

ASIC also alleges that the SQM Research reports did not accurately depict the standard, quality, value or grade of Shield, and that reflected deficiencies in the processes SQM followed.

ASIC deputy chair Sarah Court said the civil penalty proceedings against SQM Research marked the first time the regulator had taken action against a research house.

"Research houses have a responsibility to ensure they obtain the information needed to prepare their reports, take real care and skill in assessing that information and to present that information accurately," she said.

"We believe research houses are important gatekeepers and form part of a critical line of defence against poor quality investments or unsuitable products … the community is entitled to expect that their reports will be accurate and based on appropriate information and analysis."

ASIC is seeking declarations and civil penalties from the Court.

ASIC takes action against MWL Financial Services, Imperial Capital Group

ASIC will also seek to allege MWL Financial Services operated a business model, involving its former director Nicholas Maikousis and lead generator Imperial Capital Group Australia, that "provided inappropriate financial advice to clients to invest their superannuation into the Shield Master Fund".

Call for greater protections for super savings Compulsory super has led to higher levels of national savings, but, as the pool of savings grows, many argue that stricter supervision is needed to protect Australians' retirement savings.

ASIC has sought leave to commence the proceeding to allege serious failings in relation to Imperial's referral of clients to MWL and the financial advice given by MWL advisers.

ASIC has already cancelled the Australian Financial Services licence of MWL and banned Mr Maikousis from providing financial services for 10 years over conduct in relation to Shield.

ASIC has also already banned MWL's responsible manager and six former MWL financial advisers in respect of advice provided in relation to Shield.

Because MWL is in administration, ASIC's application to make its latest allegations is subject to the court's approval, or the consent of MWL's administrators, Daniel Juratowitch and Rachel Burdett of Cor Cordis.

If allowed to proceed, ASIC will seek declarations and civil penalties against all defendants, and orders disqualifying Mr Maikousis from managing corporations.

ASIC will seek to allege that between May 2022 and February 2024, nine MWL representatives advised at least 556 clients to make initial investments of about $114 million of their superannuation into Shield.

It will seek to allege that MWL failed to take reasonable steps to ensure its representatives acted in the best interests of its clients and provided appropriate advice in respect of recommendations that clients roll over their superannuation to invest into Shield as the pre-selected investment option.

ASIC will seek to allege MWL failed to ensure its financial services were provided efficiently, honestly and fairly and failed to have in place adequate arrangements to manage conflicts of interest.

It will also seek to allege that Imperial, acting as a lead generator, made misleading representations to prospective clients about the standard, quality and benefits of MWL's financial services and was involved in MWL's alleged contravention of its obligation to provide financial services efficiently, honestly and fairly.

MWL director Nicholas Maikousis was, ASIC will seek to allege, involved in MWL's alleged contraventions of its general licensee obligations and its obligation to take reasonable steps to ensure its authorised representatives complied with their best interests and related duties.

MWL, ASIC will seek to allege, received advice fees charged to clients for preparing Statements of Advice recommending investment in Shield.

Imperial received (through a related entity) about $12.8 million in payments from entities associated with Shield for client referrals and the promotion of Shield, ASIC will seek to allege.

Ms Court said the superannuation of many Australians was put at risk by the conduct proposed to be alleged in this proceeding.

"ASIC will seek to allege that MWL and Imperial were involved in a project which resulted in the superannuation of hundreds of Australians being invested into a high-risk scheme," she said.

The project allegedly involved Imperial referring prospective clients to MWL for what Imperial represented would be tailored financial advice, but which instead put clients into a pre-selected investment, Shield.

"Instead of the tailored financial advice that was promised, we will seek to allege MWL provided pre-determined advice that was not in clients' best interests," Ms Court said.

"Despite Shield having no proven track record, we will seek to allege clients were advised to invest most or almost all of their retirement savings into the fund, irrespective of their individual circumstances."

MWL and Mr Maikousis, and Imperial, were contacted for comment.

title: Piastri set for test of 'character' as F1 season unravels
text:
Mark Webber says his Formula 1 charge Oscar Piastri will have to find "deep motivations" and "character" to rebound from his recent championship woes and provide a rousing end to his 2025 season.

But even if this year's drivers' crown may now be beyond Piastri, with McLaren teammate Lando Norris 24 points clear with three grands prix remaining, manager Webber is also quick to remind everyone of the near "unprecedented" achievements of the man who is still a relative three-season novice.

Piastri finished fifth in the São Paulo Grand Prix while Norris won — the fifth race running in which the Australian missed the podium.

"I don't think he's low on motivation, put it that way," Webber said.

"He's had a tough run, but this is about character, about finding those deep motivations that you need at this point to come back."

Oscar Piastri has lost his lead to McLaren teammate Lando Norris. (Getty Images: Formula 1/Mark Sutton)

Webber, a nine-time grand prix winner who had a near-miss for the title himself in 2010 when leading with three races to go before eventually finishing third behind champion Sebastian Vettel, knows all about the pressures of a title run-in.

Why Piastri was handed a controversial 10-second penalty in Brazil Oscar Piastri was involved in the biggest flashpoint of the Formula 1 São Paulo Grand Prix, earning him a costly penalty and damaging his chances of winning the drivers' championship.

But, whatever the result of the 2025 campaign, Webber felt it should still be considered just what an achievement it has been for Piastri to win seven grands prix in only his third season of F1.

"It's obviously an incredible journey so early in his career to fight for a world title. Year three is pretty unprecedented — I think there was Lewis [Hamilton] but there haven't been many people that have done this so early in his career," he said.

"When I went for my championship, I was an old dog. I was really old at the end of my career. He's early in his career, so there's different nuances there."

Webber said he was working to ensure Piastri's head did not drop despite the recent disappointments.

"There's a bit of everything — arm around him, a bit of encouragement here and there, opportunities. You can see his pecker's up, he's still working hard, and it's early in his career.

"To see him so young, year three, fighting for a world title quite quickly, it's pretty surreal and bizarre. A lot of drivers don't fight for a title once in their career, so you've got to try and find the positives."

AAP

title: Gold Coast police officer's pull-up world record marred by online abuse
text:
Gold Coast police officer Jade Henderson is used to dealing with challenging situations, but she wasn't prepared for the barrage of abuse she received after breaking the Guinness World Record for the most pull-ups in an hour.

"I wasn't expecting to receive half the amount of attention I have received already, so when I saw that a lot of it was negative comments accusing me of being on steroids or cheating, it's quite disheartening to see that," she said.

The 32-year-old set a new world record on August 22 this year with 733 pull-ups, beating the previous record of 725 set in 2016.

Jade initially went for the 24-hour pull-up record but got injured. (Supplied: Jade Henderson)

The senior constable had originally aimed for the 24-hour pull-up record but set a smaller goal after tearing her biceps.

"I had to have a couple of weeks off to recover — it was around five weeks — and then I thought, 'Why not attempt the one-hour record instead?' Because … that prevents me from re-injuring myself and it's more manageable for my body," she said.

Henderson said she was confident she would be able to break the record, but the final 20 minutes of her attempt was tough.

"I felt my hands just rip and I just thought, 'They're already ripped. They can't get any worse, so you've got to make it worth it," she said.

In late September, she received official confirmation from Guinness World Records that her attempt had been verified as successful.

Jade Henderson secured the world record with 733 pull-ups. (Supplied: Jade Henderson)

Henderson was overwhelmed, but said her achievement had been marred by personal insults online.

"It discredits the amount of work that's actually gone into doing this record," she said.

"But I try not to focus on it, and those who love me, my family, friends, they know that I have not cheated.

"I've never done steroids, so I don't have anything to prove to anyone else."

Women in sport often targeted

Deakin University associate professor Kim Toffoletti said Henderson's experience mirrored findings from research she co-authored about sportswomen being subjected to online harm.

"When women succeed in these kinds of spaces, there is that online backlash, that desire to bring women down and to challenge that they potentially can succeed in these spaces and, in some instances, actually do better than men," she said.

"And that really poses a threat to social ideas of the natural order or that men are naturally superior in sport."

Kim Toffoletti says the abuse of female athletes online is all too common. (Supplied)

The Deakin study — which surveyed 138 professional and semi-professional athletes from 32 sports — found the most common examples of gendered online harm were personal insults (81 per cent), hate speech (62 per cent), attempts to embarrass (60 per cent) and general and sexual harassment (50 per cent and 39 per cent respectively).

But Dr Toffoletti said the most significant finding was that an overwhelming majority of sportswomen said online abuse impacted their well-being.

"Even if athletes themselves aren't being targeted personally, if they're witnessing other women who are succeeding in sport spaces and places being attacked, that also impacts their wellbeing because it says something about the fact that they're not welcome or they're seen as their achievements are not being recognised," she said.

Not backing down

Henderson said she was not going let the online trolls stop her from achieving her next goal.

"I'd like to achieve the Guinness World Record for the most pull-ups in one minute before the end of this year," she said.

She hopes to inspire others to chase their dreams, no matter what opposition they may face.

"Just believe in yourself," Henderson said.

"I know it sounds corny, but the mental aspect of it makes such a huge difference, and the saying is, 'Believe you can and you're halfway there' — and I think that's very true."

title: Inpex gas plant worker speaks out over fears he's breathing in toxic chemicals
text:
A worker at gas giant Inpex claims he was exposed to dangerous air pollutants and made to clean up an oil spill — alleging that inside one of Australia's biggest gas companies, complaints about health and safety are being brushed aside.

James — whose name has been changed for privacy and security reasons — has worked at the Ichthys onshore gas processing facility, operated by Japanese company Inpex, on Darwin Harbour for several years.

He said workers had repeatedly raised concerns about toxic chemical emissions, oil spills and maintenance in recent years, only to be dismissed.

"They've prioritised production over the environment and over safety," he said.

" I've seen the attitude and the way management treats environmental issues ... it's all a bit of a joke. "

James's concerns echo those of other Inpex workers who have contacted the Australian Workers' Union (AWU) with similar worries about the air they are breathing at the facility.

Caleb Burke from the AWU said some workers had reported being burnt from oil spills and described a toxic workplace culture where employees feared speaking out.

But Inpex senior vice president Bill Townsend insisted the company was committed to the safety of workers and the broader community, and the protection of the environment.

Inpex's Ichthys LNG onshore facility on Darwin Harbour processes gas. (ABC News: Dane Hirst)

Documents show that in April 2023, Inpex reported a 30,000 litre "heating medium" oil spill, some of which leached into stormwater drains and mangroves at Darwin Harbour where locals fish.

A separate report lodged two weeks earlier disclosed a 75,000 litre oil spill.

James claimed that after those spills, the problem tubes, towering roughly 30 metres high, were merely "bandaided with a series of plugs" by the company, instead of being properly maintained — a fix he described as a "ticking time bomb" that left many workers uneasy.

Inpex did not respond to questions from the ABC about staff warnings being ignored and concerns about maintenance on the tubes.

On October 12, 2025, Inpex reported a "heating medium" oil spill at the Ichthys facility, some of which leaked into mangroves at Darwin Harbour. (Supplied. )

'No increased health risks', Inpex says

Inpex is currently under federal investigation, following another oil spill in October this year and revelations it under-reported emissions of toxic chemicals in 2023-24.

Inpex originally reported it only emitted four tonnes of benzene, classified by the World Health Organization as a class 1 carcinogen known to cause some cancers. But last month the company admitted the true figure was more than 500 tonnes — a more than 13,000 per cent increase.

Other volatile organic compounds (VOCs) linked with health risks, including toluene, were also drastically revised up.

Inpex's senior vice president has maintained there is no increased health risk to workers and the public from the emissions.

"Inpex's workforce has been briefed there is no cause for health concern, given ongoing air quality monitoring — both on site and in the Darwin region — has consistently shown emissions levels are well within government guidelines," Mr Townsend said.

He said Inpex's monitoring sites were independently verified and its "worker health monitoring program" had never detected benzene.

On top of that, he noted that on October 31, the NT Chief Health Officer Paul Burgess had concluded "there is no evidence of increased health risks".

Inpex ships gas to Japan. (Supplied: Inpex)

However, the NT government's own air quality monitors cannot detect benzene or other VOCs.

In response to questions from the ABC, the NT Department of Health conceded the chief health officer had come to his conclusion using data provided by Inpex.

"This data was from Inpex's monthly and continuous ambient air monitoring at several locations required under NT environmental and work health and safety laws," a health department spokesperson told the ABC.

The spokesperson said the NT EPA and chief health officer had ordered an independent review of Inpex's data "to verify that previous emissions did not pose a risk to the community".

'Smells like rotten eggs', worker claims

Mr Burke from the AWU, which represents Inpex employees, said workers at the Darwin facility had "repeatedly" raised health and safety concerns with Inpex's management, but felt like "nothing was being done".

Federal investigation into Inpex An oil spill that leaked into Darwin Harbour and the substantial under-reporting of toxic chemical emissions have put one of Australia's biggest gas companies under federal investigation.

He said workers alleged that in the aftermath of the oil spill in October this year, "it wasn't uncommon" for people working in the vicinity to suffer burns from hot oil dropping on them.

Others who had reached out to him raising fears about exposure to pollution and safety standards in recent weeks feared voicing their concerns and had asked to remain anonymous.

"A lot of [members] worry that their job is going to be put in jeopardy because they're speaking out," he said.

James said he was not convinced by Inpex's assurances that emission levels are safe at the facility. When he reports for work, he said, he worries about the air he is breathing.

"When the wind's blowing the wrong way you can smell the gasses," he said.

"H2S (hydrogen sulphide) is probably the most pungent, it's a sulphury smell like rotten eggs … if you can smell that, there's others as well."

" It makes your eyes water. "

Inpex is Japan's largest oil and gas exploration and production company. (Supplied: Inpex)

He said when he complained to management, he was told "not to worry about it".

"My partner is deeply concerned," he said.

"We've all got families and kids."

The ABC put multiple questions to Inpex about worker complaints and accounts of a toxic workplace, but did not receive a direct response.

In response to workers' claims about emissions, Mr Townsend said routine monitoring demonstrated the facility was "well below Safe Work Australia’s hydrogen sulphide 10 parts per million exposure limit".

'Nothing to worry about here', not adequate, expert says

Documents submitted to a Senate inquiry last year revealed that Inpex's acid gas incinerators — anti-pollution systems designed to burn off toxic chemicals — had been out of service for extended periods since 2019, including a stretch of 323 days in 2023 and more than 143 days last year.

"When they are not running you can actually smell the hydrogen sulphide," James said.

Shay Dougall, a workplace health and safety expert, said it was likely the incinerators had been neglected because of the high cost of fixing them, but she said letting them break down was "unacceptable".

She said if emissions of toxic chemicals could not be controlled by some other means, the facility should be shut down.

"[For Inpex to say], 'Oh, there's nothing to worry about here', is not adequate when you're talking about a class 1 carcinogen [benzene]," she said.

John Zorbas is the president of the Australian Medical Association NT. (ABC News: Pete Garnish)

Australian Medical Association NT president John Zorbas also said he was worried about the chemicals being discharged into the air from the facility and expressed concerns for the health of residents in nearby Darwin and Palmerston.

He said he was calling for the NT chief health officer to do his own investigation, separate from the EPA, to rule out long-term cancer risks.

"This is a significant public health issue," he said.

In September, a "scandal" surrounding a Santos gas tank exposed years of inaction and a potential conflict of interest inside the territory's environmental regulator, which some critics believe has shattered trust in its ability to oversee northern Australia's rapidly expanding gas industry.

But an NT EPA spokesperson said it was "committed to conducting a thorough investigation into environmental and human health risks" at the Inpex facility.

The NT EPA has appointed independent investigators to examine Inpex's reporting failures and possible breaches of legislation, the spokesperson said.

NT EPA chair Paul Vogel was taken off the investigation last month to rule out a conflict of interest, though he denies any conflict.

Inpex did not answer detailed questions from the ABC, but in a statement Mr Townsend said "working safely is Inpex's priority, always. This commitment underpins our approach to protecting people and the environment."

title: 'Vault' sculptor denies backing council's 'silly' PR stunt
text:
The artist whose controversial sculpture Vault headlines the regional Victorian town of Mildura's new tourism campaign says it is a "profoundly silly" PR stunt.

Last week Mildura Rural City Council unveiled a Bring Vault Home campaign which intends to take Ron Robertson-Swann's yellow sculpture from outside the Australian Centre for Contemporary Art in Southbank and place it on the lawns of the Mildura Arts Centre.

The controversial sculpture was installed in Melbourne's City Square in 1980 and moved to its current site in 2002.

Last week the Mildura council said Mr Robertson-Swann had "welcomed the proposal" but that seems not to be the case.

Ron Robertson Swann, in an undated photo with Vault at its present site, says the "silliness" of the campaign frustrates him. (Supplied: Australian Galleries)

Speaking to the ABC, the artist said the campaign was "a silly beat up to get publicity".

"I thought it was silly but they went ahead with it," Mr Robertson-Swann said.

"I couldn't stop them from doing that. That's their business.

"They're happy, I think, because this is all going on now and they feel they've really seriously generated something, but it's hollow.

"It's completely hollow and it's probably, if anything, exposing the stupidity.

" The silliness of it frustrates me. "

The sculpture Vault by artist Ron Robertson-Swann in Melbourne. (774 ABC Melbourne: Simon Leo Brown)

AI used in campaign video

The Bring Vault Home campaign is the beginning of a wider tourism promotion portraying Mildura as regional Victoria's new arts and culture capital.

It included a video fronted by actor and Mildura's tourism ambassador, Shane Jacobson.

The video, which the council confirmed used AI, shows a crowd gathered in front of the sculpture wanting to bring it "home".

Mildura's "Bring Vault Home" campaign shows distortions that are a hallmark of some AI-generated videos. (Supplied: Facebook )

"The Vault has been under-appreciated, undervalued, unloved. It's even been mocked in Melbourne for way too long — we are talking decades," Jacobson says in the video.

Beethoven is displayed in front of the Mildura Arts Centre. (ABC News: Nethma Dandeniya)

Cost to relocate Vault

Mr Robertson-Swann said the City of Melbourne owned Vault and it would cost well over $1 million to move it to Mildura.

"I think it's profoundly silly, because ... Mildura has no intention of spending any money," he said.

"The only money they spent was on phone calls to start this beat up.

" If Mildura council was at all serious, they should start purchasing a few more sculptures for ... the gallery. "

In response, Mildura Rural City Council said Mr Robertson-Swann had "indicated he was supportive of the initiative" when consulted.

"We have enormous respect for Ron Robertson-Swann's artwork, which is why we are asking for Vault to join its little brother, [the sculpture] Beethoven, and we'd certainly like to see more sculptures in Mildura and the broader region," said the council's strategy and growth general manager Phil Stone.

"We have invited Ron and his wife to visit Mildura and we're looking forward to hosting them when they arrive."

Councillor dissent

City of Melbourne Lord Mayor Nick Reece has rejected Mildura's Vault heist attempt, saying the sculpture belongs in Melbourne.

However, fellow councillor and portfolio lead for creative and arts Philip Lui disagreed.

"If there is a serious proposal, if there is a serious interest, I don't think we should be just putting up a straight 'no'," Cr Lui said.

"I want to hear what the reason is, what's the proposal, how they're going to look after it, what's the interest?

"Because ultimately public art is for the public, if there is interest in it, and given that we are the leaders in the local government sector we do, I think, have to show leadership."

title: Cost of living crisis affecting single parents and families most
text:
Single mum Tara Weldon holds a well-paid job working four days a week, but admits she sometimes struggles to put food on the table for her two kids.

The Redfern mother says she spends at least $250 a week on food for herself and her children.

"That would normally be someone's fortnightly shopping back a good six years ago, and now it's like, it's pretty much doubled."

Tara Weldon admits it is getting harder to put food on the table for her two children. (ABC Radio Sydney: Declan Bowring)

To help with the cost of groceries, she picks up a free bag of fruit and vegetables from food relief charity OzHarvest at the Redfern Community Centre every week.

The bags usually contain fresh fruit, vegetables and occasionally meat, eggs and pastries.

The majority of deliveries are fresh fruit and vegetables, but occasionally there is also meat and eggs. (Supplied: OzHarvest)

"For some reason on Mondays, I'm always in need, or a bit short, or haven't done the groceries," Ms Weldon said.

"If I didn't have that pick-up … I don't know what I'd be going home to feed my children with, like, they'd be having Weet-Bix, or probably two-minute noodles instead of nutritional food.

" It goes a long way. "

Mother-of-three Dominica Siu, who also occasionally collects a food bag from the community centre, says she is feeling the pinch from the rising cost of living. Her weekly grocery bill amounts to about $300.

"It's tough with three kids, expenses and school expenses," Ms Siu said.

Dominica Siu says the grocery bill is now around $300 a week for her family. (ABC News: Declan Bowring)

"If I haven't done my shopping, it [the OzHarvest pack] will last for my lunches, and midweek I've got enough food for school lunches and breakfasts.

"It assists with what I can currently afford and support."

As well as providing produce for the grocery bags, OzHarvest also runs a monthly food truck that serves free lunches outside the community centre.

About 20 to 40 people come to the community centre to collect grocery bags every week, says Tracey Duncan, who manages Aboriginal city spaces with the City of Sydney, including Redfern Community Centre.

OzHarvest delivers more than 200kg of food per week to the community centre. (Supplied: OzHarvest)

Ms Duncan says the bags are often gone by the end of the afternoon.

She says occasionally the grocery bags have meat in them, which is often what members of the community are cutting back on because of how much it costs.

"The cost of living is absolutely crazy," Ms Duncan said.
