title: Aus’ big move on US tech titans
text:
Tech firms could be slapped with millions in new fines if they fail to ink content deals with Australian media under a new regime proposed by Labor.

The Albanese government on Thursday released a consultation paper on its News Bargaining Incentive.

Building on the News Media and Digital Platforms Mandatory Bargaining Code introduced by the Coalition in 2021, platforms that make at least $250m in revenue from Australian sources would be covered.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

They may not even need to host Australian news content.

News Corp Australiasia executive chairman Michael Miller welcomed the update.

“The News Bargaining Incentive’s importance has only escalated since it was announced almost a year ago in terms of how we function successfully as a nation,” Mr Miller said.

“This is the clearest indication yet that the government will continue its good work to stand up for local Australian communities by asserting news media’s enduring importance in shaping our national stories, identity and, ultimately, our democratic way of life.”

Assistant Treasurer Dan Mulino has played down concerns Labor’s proposal could draw ire from US President Donald Trump. Picture: NewsWire / Monique Harmer

Meanwhile, the minister spearheading the incentive played down concerns it could draw ire from Donald Trump.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

The US President has long-warned countries against digital taxes and regulations that could, as he sees it, rip off American tech titans.

But Assistant Treasurer and Finance Minister Dan Mulino said the proposal took an “agnostic” approach to a company’s country of origin.

“I want to stress that this is agnostic as to the location of the companies,” he told reporters in Sydney.

“Based upon the coverage criteria that are spelt out in this consultation paper, we expect that the companies that will be covered will include Meta, Google and TikTok.

“So there are two US companies and one company not based in the US.

“So this is not about where companies are located – this is about issues relating to market power and the use of news content without appropriate, fair compensation.”

title: Libs scrap net zero after secret meeting
text:
The Liberal Party has followed the Nationals in scrapping Australia’s target of net zero emissions by 2050, bringing the Coalition a step closer to unity on climate policy.

Sussan Ley convened Liberal members of her shadow cabinet on Thursday to finalise a formal position and put an end to months of bitter infighting.

NewsWire understands participants agreed to dump the target in favour of short-term targets.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

They also agreed to stay in the Paris Agreement.

Opposition energy spokesman Dan Tehan is set to hold a press conference to formally announce the position before a Liberal delegation meets with National Party counterparts to hash out a joint position.

The Coalition signed Australia up to net zero by 2050 under the Scott Morrison in 2021.

More to come.

‘Clownshow’

Earlier, Anthony Albanese slammed the Liberals’ internal divisions over net zero as a “clownshow”, accusing the party of climate denialism.

On Wednesday, Liberal MPs and senators emerged from a mammoth meeting designed for the party room to express their views on the emissions target, which was adopted under the Scott Morrison-led Coalition.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

The policy was put under review by Sussan Ley after the opposition’s historic loss at polling booths in May, and has since fractured the Coalition across party lines.

The Prime Minister told reporters in Sydney on Thursday the opposition was considering walking away from net zero because “they fundamentally do not believe in the science in climate change”.

The Coalition approach to energy would “hurt Australians”, Anthony Albanese said. Picture: NewsWire / Martin Ollman

“Australians cannot afford to keep paying the price of Coalition infighting when it comes to climate policy and energy policy,” he said.

Scenes of the Liberal Party’s right faction, entering the Wednesday party room meeting as a bloc, was a sign the opposition were “a divided rabble”, Mr Albanese said.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

“It’s a show of division,” he said.

“These were people who, many of whom, have either challenged or resigned from the front bench.

“You had Angus Taylor walking with his counterparts - this was a sign of opposition to Sussan Ley’s leadership, and it was a rather extraordinary moment.

“And the pictures (were) very deliberate for people to gather beforehand in formation in order to send that message, and that message was surely received, not so much by the party room, because that’s a matter for them, their clownshow that they’ve become.

“It was a sign for the Australian people, of how divided they are.”

Libs ‘optimistic’ after meeting

A Liberal backbencher has revealed details about the highly secretive, marathon meeting in Parliament House, following reports the party room majority expressed views to drop net zero.

The right faction, led by Sarah Henderson and Jacinta Nampijinpa Price, showed up to the Wednesday meeting as a unit. Picture: NewsWire / Martin Ollman

Opposition communications spokeswoman Melissa McIntosh, who has publicly advocated for the party to abandon the emissions target, said the meeting left MPs and senators feeling “optimistic”, adding that she had a “spring in (her) step”.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

“It was really civilised, and people got to have their say, it did go for five hours,” she told Sky News on Thursday.

“We all had about five minutes each to express our views.

“So it was a productive day, and we’ve still got another session today with the shadow ministry.’

Asked point-blank whether the party had formally dumped net zero, Ms McIntosh said she was feeling “quite optimistic” and hoped the final policy would take that position.

“I can’t say formally yet, because we do have to go into the shadow ministry meeting, and there are people in that meeting who probably support net zero for their various reasons, and it will be up to Dan (Tehan) and Sussan (Ley) to negotiate our way through that.

Melissa McIntosh has been an outspoken critic of net zero. Picture: NewsWire / Martin Ollman

“But yesterday’s purpose was for everyone to express their views, their opinions about it, and some people like myself went in strong on the basis that that’s what their community wants.”

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

The Paris Agreement was also brought up in the party room meeting, she said, with “strong support” for a commitment to stay in the international climate treaty, “across the board”.

“There was no dissenting issues around Paris.

“I think it’s important for us to continue to uphold our international obligations when it comes to climate and emissions reduction.

“Everyone that stood up against net zero still stood up and said that we do have a role to play in bringing down emissions, just not this harder, faster, deeper pace that we’re going (at), that the Albanese Labor Government has set us on.”

Dan Tehan is responsible for drafting the Liberal Party’s official energy policy. Picture: NewsWire / Martin Ollman

Asked how the party would argue that dropping net zero wasn’t synonymous with climate denialism, Ms McIntosh said: “It’s going to be up to us as a party to strongly articulate the reasons why we are making these decisions.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

“We’d have to be have our head in the sand to think that we’re not going to receive attacks from all sorts of angles on this.

“But the intent is strong. We do care about the environment, we do care about climate policy, and we do care about Australians, but when people are suffering so badly right now … we can’t expect that things are going to change if we don’t change direction.

Most Liberals, including opposition energy spokesman Dan Tehan, who is drafting the party’s official position, have hinted coal and gas will play a role in the new policy platform.

However, Ms McIntosh said it would be up to Mr Tehan and Ms Ley to determine the “nuts and bolts” of the Liberal Party’s final policy platform, which is due to be announced on Thursday afternoon.
